thread.title: The Morning Ledger: Volkswagen's CEO Set to Be Replaced

title: The Morning Ledger: Volkswagen's CEO Set to Be Replaced
text:
0 COMMENTS 
Sign up for the Morning Ledger, emailed to you each weekday morning. Follow us on Twitter: @CFOJournal. All CFO Journal-produced content can be accessed without a subscription. Volkswagen CEO Matthias Müller is pictured in November 2016. The car maker’s supervisory board is expected to vote on Friday to replace him with VW brand chief Herbert Diess. AFP/Getty Images 
Good morning. No matter how exemplary a job an executive might do, maintaining shareholders’ backing is paramount. The supervisory board of Volkswagen AG is expected to vote to replace Chief Executive Matthias Müller on Friday, people familiar with the situation told the WSJ’s William Boston. If the move happens, it would mark a stunning turn for the CEO credited with steering the German car maker through its emissions scandal. 
Volkswagen isn’t just any other company, as it is controlled by a distinctive trio of stakeholders. The heirs to Ferdinand Porsche and the German state of Lower Saxony together hold more than 70% of the company’s voting stock, while the IG Metall trade union has 10 seats on its board of directors. 
Meanwhile, Volkswagen’s finance chief Frank Witter is expected to stay put in the event of a new CEO appointment, report CFO Journal’s Nina Trentmann and Mr. Boston. Mr. Witter took the CFO seat shortly after Volkswagen’s emission cheating became public in September 2015, and helped guide the company through the fallout. 
“Mr. Witter is seen as an anchor of stability at Volkswagen,” said Jürgen Pieper, senior advisor at B. Metzler seel. Sohn & Co. Holding AG , a German bank. “He is firmly in the saddle,” Mr. Pieper said. 
THE DAY AHEAD 
The U.S. Federal Reserve on Wednesday will offer more details on policy makers’ outlook for 2018 when it releases the minutes of their March 20-21 meeting. Here’s what to watch. 
Facebook testimony continues. Facebook Inc. CEO Mark Zuckerberg is returning to Capitol Hill for a second day of extended testimony over the company’s handling of user privacy. On Tuesday, lawmakers criticized Mr. Zuckerberg for a lack of transparency, repeatedly expressing discontent with Facebook’s handling of a series of scandals in which the privacy of millions of users was violated. 
Bed Bath & Beyond Inc. is among companies slated to report earnings today. 
CORPORATE NEWS The YouTube logo is displayed as video creators participate in a workshop in Tokyo, Japan, March 2013. Bloomberg News 
Investors want to know more about YouTube. A number of investors are asking Alphabet Inc. to share sales and profit information about its YouTube unit, arguing the video site has become a material part of the company’s business but remains a financial enigma. 
Sprint, T-Mobile restart deal talks. Sprint Corp. and T-Mobile U.S. Inc. have rekindled merger talks, as the wireless rivals explore a combination for the third time in four years. 
Boeing, Airbus boost jet backlogs. Boeing Co. and Airbus SE on Tuesday added orders for jets valued at more than $10 billion, adding pressure on both to boost production. Meanwhile, Airbus investor DWS Group has asked management to provide additional information involving investigations of possible wrongdoing at the company, reports MarketWatch. 
Exxon, Qatar discuss potential U.S. shale deal. Exxon Mobil Corp. is in talks with Qatar over a partnership that could see the Middle Eastern nation owning U.S. gas, people familiar with the matter said. 
Theranos lays off most of its remaining workforce. Blood-testing firm Theranos Inc. laid off most of its remaining workforce in a last-ditch effort to preserve cash and avert or at least delay bankruptcy for a few more months, according to people familiar with the matter. 
China’s HNA nets windfall as it exits Hilton investment early. An early exit from an investment in hotel chain Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc. has proved highly profitable for China’s HNA Group Co. The indebted conglomerate stands to collect around $2 billion in profits from its $6.5 billion Hilton investment. 
Kroger to hire more supermarket workers. Kroger Co. is hiring 11,000 workers to improve customer service and efficiency at its stores as competition among food retailers heats up. 
Carl Icahn to sell Federal-Mogul for $2.44 billion. Carl Icahn’s company is selling a car-parts maker it has controlled since 2008 for about $2.44 billion, hiving off a piece of an auto empire that includes holdings in rental services, ride hailing and repair shops. 
Tishman Speyer inks deal with Pfizer. Developer Tishman Speyer has closed a large lease deal with pharmaceutical company Pfizer Inc. at its Hudson Yards tower and has secured financing to move ahead with the $3.7 billion project, Tishman said. 
Private-equity firm Altaris to acquire Analogic for $1.1 billion. Private-equity firm Altaris Capital Partners LLC has agreed to buy Analogic Corp. for about $1.1 billion, as the maker of medical-imaging and security-screening systems faces increasingly competitive markets. 
Alexion to buy Wilson Therapeutics. Alexion Pharmaceuticals Inc. has made a $788 million bid for Swedish biopharmaceutical company Wilson Therapeutics AB as it looks to bolster its portfolio of treatments for rare disorders, reports Reuters. 
Tesco profits jump. U.K. grocer Tesco PLC declared its first year-end dividend in four years after posting a sharp rise in annual profits. 
REGULATION Federal Reserve Board Chairman Jerome Powell testifies during a hearing on Capitol Hill, Washington, D.C., U.S., March 1, 2018. Getty Images 
Fed floats first major big-bank rule change of Trump era. In the first major big-bank rule change of the Trump era, the Federal Reserve proposed retooling capital rules and annual “stress tests” for the largest U.S. financial firms. 
Sinclair faces federal resistance over proposed purchase of Tribune Media. Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. is encountering resistance from the U.S. Federal Communications Commission as it seeks approval for its $3.9 billion acquisition of Tribune Media Co. 
EU raids offices in sports broadcasting probe. The European Commission raided the offices of several companies involved in sports broadcasting rights, including Fox Networks Group, a unit of 21st Century Fox Inc., as part of an investigation into a possible cartel, reports Reuters. 
Sanctions expected to prevent Rusal from paying eurobond. United Co. Rusal PLC, the world’s second-largest aluminum producer, is unlikely to be able to pay a eurobond coupon in May as a result of U.S. sanctions imposed on the Russian company last week, reports Reuters. Meanwhile, Swiss engineering firm Sulzer AG is trying to distance itself from its Russian owners after the U.S. targeted allies of Vladimir Putin in the latest round of sanctions. 
Shanghai, London stock exchanges to get trading link. China’s central bank governor promised to expand foreign access to the country’s banking, securities and insurance sectors and open a trading link between the Shanghai and London stock exchanges, all by year’s end. 
ECONOMY Dole bananas are displayed in a supermarket in Pittsburgh, Pa., Feb. 22, 2018. AP 
Why retailers, not consumers, pay more for bananas. The price that stores paid for bananas hit a record high in the first quarter, pressured by limited supplies in Central and South America, which produce most bananas sold in the U.S. But few retailers passed that cost to consumers as bananas drive trips to the store because they are an item that most people go out to purchase rather than buy online. 
Saudi bond sale raises $11 billion. Saudi Arabia surprised investors Tuesday with the abrupt sale of $11 billion in bonds, roiling its rival Qatar’s plans to raise debt and fueling concerns that a diplomatic standoff was bleeding into the financial world. 
U.S. business price growth hotter than expected. A gauge of U.S. business prices grew more than expected in March, the latest sign inflation pressures may be building in the economy. 
U.K. factory output declines. British manufacturing output fell unexpectedly in February, its first month-on-month drop in almost a year, adding to signs the economy may have slowed in the first quarter, reports Reuters. 
CFO MOVES 
Remington Outdoor Co. , a Madison, N.C. manufacturer of firearms, said its Chief Financial Officer Steve Jackson is resigning to take on a similar role at another company, effective April 19. Until a new CFO is appointed, the company intends to fulfill the role’s obligations with its existing team, it said in a release. 
Sempra Energy , a San Diego, Calif., utility company, appointed Trevor I. Mihalik executive vice president and CFO, effective May 1. Mr. Mihalik joined the company in 2012 as controller and chief accounting officer and was promoted to senior vice president in 2013. Previously, Mihalik served as senior vice president of finance at a U.S. subsidiary of Iberdrola SA. 
Mr. Mihalik’s annual salary will be increased to $600,000 and his target bonus under the company’s annual incentive plan will be raised to 80% of his annual salary. An incremental award of restricted stock units with a grant date value of $414,000 was granted to Mr. Mihalik with an effective grant date of May 1, 2018, according to a filing. These units vest over two years with 50% of the units vesting on the first anniversary of the date of grant and the remainder vesting on the second anniversary of the date of grant. Mr. Mihalik’s current target for future annual long-term incentive awards will be increased to 210% of his annual salary. 
The Morning Ledger from CFO Journal cues up the most important news in corporate finance every weekday morning. Nina Trentmann contributed to today’s Ledger. Send tips, suggestions and complaints to the editor: kimberly.johnson@wsj.com. Share this:
